Description:
A mortgage contract:

  • Two brothers of poor means 
  • Mortgage two parts of their inherited estate (two and half mou of land) for four years
  • Mortgage land to their neighbour Luo Sichao
  • 15 piculs of wheat given as mortgage
  • Two witnesses to the contract named
Difficulties using this object: This contract is complete, but it is difficult to contextualise. We do not know what happened before or after, nor do we know exactly where it took place.
Use of this object: It tells us about the value of land in this time period and the way in which mortgage contracts were written and authenticated.

Description:
• Important local Buddhist composition from Khotan. 
  • It is a ‘metrical’ or poetic account of various different aspects of Buddhism. 
  • It also tells significance in the history of Khotanese Buddhism.
  • It is an important source in deciphering the Old Khotanese language.
Difficulties using this object:
• Some words from the documents have been disappeared and sides of the document are also torn a part which makes it difficult to interpret some words.  
  • The original title of the text is also unknown.
Use of this object:
• This document tells us how different aspects of Buddhism was spread at that time through a poetic language which usually attracts people.
  •  Moreover, it also tells us about the importance of Khotanese language as numerous copies were made up until 10th century.

Description:
• This piece of document is from a Tangut copy of the Mahaprajnaparamita sutra which was discovered in Kharakhoto. 

  • The Mahaprajnaparamita sutra is a collection of Prajna Paramita sutras.

  • They used to translate sutras into the Tangut language.
Difficulties using this object:
• The document is damaged and torn, some letters are also not clearly visible because of some liquid. This makes it hard to understand the full sentence.
  • The document only has the last chunk left. As a result we have a big chunk missing from the start.
Use of this object: It tells how much the Tangut Empire gave importance to their religion and how the people spread Buddhism through translating the Buddhist text into Tangut language.

Description: This is a complete, but much discoloured and rotted document on leather. The Kharosthi scripts at the front of the tablet are cursive, black and partly deleted.
Difficulties using this object: It is a bit torn from the middle and the ink is faded, which is why it can't be read properly
Use of this object: It can provide insights into ancient languages, scripts, historical events, religious practices, trade, governance, and societal structures. It can be invaluable for historians, archaeologists, linguists, and scholars studying the ancient civilizations of the region. They contribute to our understanding of the past and help piece together the puzzle of human history.

Description:
Rong Xinjiang identifies this as a late document from Turfan.

Height 37.1 centimetres, width 38.1 centimetres

Material Used: Manuscript and Ink on Paper
Difficulties using this object: The ink is a bit faded
Use of this object:
It can offer valuable clues about Turfan and the society that produced it.

 It could also hold significant historical or cultural value.

Document name: Ink and color on paper: Six female spirits to protect children.
Description:
• Three Pōthī fols. with paintings of demons, and Chin. and Brāhmī inscriptions referring to same. 

    •  Six demons, painted and occupying one half of leaf in both cases.

    • The upper half of the object depicts a figure with a stag's head and partially preserved deer hooves. It holds a young child in its arms. 

    • On the reverse side, there is a figure with an ox's head and hooves, with dark blue flesh. It holds a noose in its right hand, and there's an undetermined object in its left hand. 

  • Between the feet of the figure on the reverse side, there lies an infant wrapped in swaddling bands.
Difficulties using this object:
• The document has been written in two languages.
  • It is a mythical document mostly reflecting the beliefs of the people in spiritual beings. So, it is hard to understand and contextualise as it is difficult to predict from the document that the demons/spirits are intended to protect children.
  • Moreover, the document has being torn in centre and sides.
  • The ink and colour on the paper is also faded a little bit.
Use of this object:
• This document could have been used in spiritual context to protect children from evil.
  • Could have been used as decorative or symbolic elements in temples, shrines, and ceremonial places.
  • Its usage might be connected with the belief system of people of ancient times.

Description:
• A legal contract concerning water rights written on a double wooden tablet.
  • This was acquired by the British Consul-General in Kashgar, N. Fitzmaurice, Esq., and presented to the British Museum on 14 July 1923. It is probably from around Dandan-Uliq.
  • It contains two versions of the same document, the one written on the inside of the cover and the top of the undertablet is more extensive.
  • It concerns the sale of water rights from a pool by the judge Bara and Bramgala to Yagura for 2500 muras. The hole on the top is for a clay seal.
Difficulties using this object:
• The tablet has dark and light shades. Dark for the regions that are exposed to moisture and the ink on wood in dark regions is faded so it is hard to read.
  • The structure of the document is unique and is difficult to predict the reason behind documenting a legal contract in this form.
Use of this object: It tells us about the value of water in this time period and the way legal contracts were written. It also shows the creativity of people living in this time period.

Document name: Paper Fragment, Document On Leather, Fragment
Description: This document consists of 2 pieces of leather fragments. There is a date in short 1.Khar. with numerals clearly and easily found on the back of the fragments.
Difficulties using this object:
1) Leather fragments may be incomplete or damaged, making it challenging to decipher the entire text or understand its context.

2) Understanding the cultural and linguistic context of the inscription may require knowledge of ancient languages and historical cultures associated with the Silk Road.

3) Even when the script is deciphered , interpreting the meaning of the text and its significance within the historical context can be subjective and open to interpretation.
Use of this object:
1) Dates, events, and historical contexts mentioned in these fragments contribute to the chronological reconstruction of Silk Road history, enabling historians to map out the development and evolution of societies and cultures over time.

2)They provide evidence of the types of materials and goods exchanged along the Silk Road, shedding light on trade routes, commodities, and cultural interactions.

3) By studying the content of these fragments, we can gain insights into the daily lives, customs, beliefs, and social structures of the people living along the Silk Road, enriching our understanding of ancient civilizations.

Description: Silk MS.-roll cover, complete. Body made of rectang. piece of plain pink silk, backed with coarse paper, and stiffened with wooden strainer at each end. All round a 2″ border of thick figured silk, and at one end are attached three broad bands of same—one in middle projecting c. 8″ beyond edge of cover, and one at each side of it converging to meet the first near its outer end. To either end of middle band are sewn tapes of coarse linen for tying up cover when rolled round manuscript.
Difficulties using this object:
1)The delicate nature of silk and paper means that the articles may be prone to damage, decay, or deterioration over time, making it difficult to handle and preserve.

2)Deciphering the meaning of symbols and patterns on paper and silk may require lingusitic knowledge and expertise.
Use of this object:
1) Studying this object can provide clues about social hierarchies, economic prosperity, and cultural patronage along the Silk Road.

2) It offers an insight into the craftsmanship and material culture of the time period.

Document name: Pothi Buddhist manuscript in Sanskrit on silk.
Description: This is the only known example of a manuscript on silk - a tradition from China - cut into pothi shape - a tradition from south Asia. It has been covered with a chalk ground to take the ink, which has been written in pen. It was discovered below a niche, at the base of a brick stupa inside the fort at Bash-Koyumal.
Difficulties using this object:
1- This document is incomplete and damaged, which makes it difficult for the historian and people who are studying it.

2- To understand the essence of the document or the meaning of text, written on it, the people studying it need to have knowlegde of the ancient language and if language is still understandable still, reader should have some historic and contextual understanding about it.
Use of this object:
1- The manuscript's production is evidence of the well-established network of trade routes and communication channels that existed in the 11th century Buddhist world. 

2- The manuscript has been covered with chalk ground to take ink, which has been written in pen. The manuscript contains all major genres and divisions of Buddhist literature, and provides a new basis for scholarly understanding of the early history of Buddhism and the way that texts were used in early Buddhist monasteries.

Document name: Square Khotanese wooden envelope-tablet made up of two pieces of wood
Description: a square Khotanese wooden envelope-tablet made up of two pieces of wood. Clay seal, with some original cord in place. Writing on both sides of the upper and lower pieces. Dated in the first regnal year of the Great King of Khoptan, Visya Sihya (c. 737–46), it was signed by the General Visala, whose clay seal is still preserved.
Difficulties using this object: These wooden envelopes have texts on them, and the text is not clear. This makes it difficult for the reader to understand.
Use of this object: These wooden envelopes tell us that the people at that time were using letters to communicate and to carry these letters; they have created these wooden envelopes, which indicates that those people were highly skilled.

Document name: A rare example of Zoroastrian literature in Sogdian
Description: This eight or ninnth-century Sogdian manuscript found in Dunhuang, China, has a version of one of the holiest Zoroastrian prayers, the Ashem Vohu, which was originally written in the Avestan (ancient Iranian) language.
Difficulties using this object: The text presents significant challenges, including translation difficulties due to the ancient and less commonly understood Sogdian language, preservation issues with fragile manuscripts, and an in-depth knowledge of both Zoroastrian religious practices and Sogdian culture in order to fully comprehend its context and significance.
Use of this object: Academically, it is a valuable tool for researchers studying ancient faiths, languages, and the historical expansion of Zoroastrianism in Central Asia. Language researchers can utilize it to better comprehend the Sogdian language, while cultural historians can investigate Silk Road trade. This text also has religious relevance for current Zoroastrians, as it provides insights into their religious history, and it can be used to improve museum displays focusing on religion or Central Asian history.

Description: Four woodcuts on paper from the same design as depict Chinese lettering and Mañjuśrī on a lion. Poor impressions printed on a number of small squares of thin paper, pasted together to make a single sheet, and bordered with stiffer paper. Another strip of paper was attached between impressions, with a poorly drawn and painted tiny Buddha at the top and a salutation to Amitābha (?) below. Dirt obscures the lower portion of the inscr., and the sheet is often in horrible condition.
Difficulties using this object: The use of Mañjuśrī's four woodcuts may provide difficulties. Recognizing these artworks' deep cultural and religious meaning. Also, keeping antique woodcuts can be challenging; they must be protected from light, humidity, and changes in temperature to avoid harm. Displaying them properly requires certain circumstances to prevent degradation, which may limit how and where they can be displayed.
Use of this object: These tools are used in religious studies to explain and offer the qualities and stories of Mañjuśrī, a major figure in Mahayana Buddhism recognized for his wisdom. The woodcuts depicting Mañjuśrī might help focus thoughts and intentions on knowledge and enlightenment during meditation activities. They also have artistic value, and may be shown in museums or cultural exhibitions to highlight Buddhist art and iconography.

Description: It is a a rectangular covering tablet with flags of strings with a height of  0.7centimeter and width of 19.1 cm. there is a clear and well written short lines of Kharoshti script at the top edges.
Difficulties using this object: The text appeared muddled, resulting in a lack of clarity where all the words seemed to blend together
Use of this object: This has been used as document of confirmation or affidivit which has been written in the presence of the witnesses.

Description:
• Two portions of illuminated Chin. MS. roll, containing treatise on names of the Thousand Buddhas.
  • At head of each name is miniature of small seated Buddha.
Difficulties using this object: Some of names and images of buddha are missing (worn off), otherwise the document is in good condition. It has some waterspots/oilspots on the paper as well but it does not affect the text visibility.
Use of this object: • This document could have played important part in history of Buddhism as it contains almost a thousand names of Buddha which would have difficult to remember so they must have written it with small individual images of buddha.

Document name: Manuscript, Ink on Paper: Contract relating to land mortgage
Description:
• The contract details the mortgage agreement between two brothers and their neighbor Luo Sichao.
  • The agreement involves mortgaging two parcels of inherited land, totaling 2.5 mou.
  • The mortgage term is set for four years.
  • In exchange for the mortgage, the brothers receive 15 piculs of wheat.
  • The contract includes the names and identifying marks of the three men involved: the two brothers and Luo Sichao.
  • The contract is witnessed by Luo Sichao's father, Luo Anjin, and the Vinaya Master Fuhai.

Difficulties using this object:
This contract is not complete because the writings on the alternate pages are missing and it will be hard to know the reality of what is said. We will not be able to know what has happened in between the scenario, and what exactly happened at the end. Due to all this we will not be able to find the real context. 

The page numbers have not been given which will be a hindrance to reading them in order.

Some pages are in bits and pieces.
Use of this object:
The contract contains examples of ancient writing styles and language usage, providing valuable information for linguists and historians.

The contract often contains names and family relationships, which can be used to trace lineages and understand family structures

Contract reveals how legal and economic systems were structured, including land ownership.

Document name: Ink on Paper: Text relating to the upkeep of roads in Khotanese.
Description:
• General Sudarrjum issued orders for road maintenance along the Silk Road based on reports from an inspection tour.
  • Ten men were assigned to repair the road in the Pa' region, which had become difficult to travel due to being full of holes.
  • The workers were instructed to bring loads of reeds and work continuously until the repairs were completed, using the reeds to fill a pond that drains towards the town.
  • Emphasis was placed on quick action to avoid delays or excuses for inaction.
  • The document demonstrated efficient use of paper, containing different texts in Khotanese and Tibetan on both sides, indicating the importance of record-keeping and communication.

Document name: A legal contract concerning adoption of a boy written on a double wooden tablet.
Description:
•  The document describes the adoption of a boy named Haryāsaka by a man named Puñadatta to the wife his half brother Aśnadāysa.
  • This act of adoption is legally documented on the double wooden tablet, indicating the transfer of guardianship and responsibility from Puñadatta to Aśnadāysa.
  • The terms of the adoption, along with specific conditions and details, are carefully recorded in the inscription by the scribe Bihera, ensuring the legality and recognition of the adoption process.
Difficulties using this object: There no such visible difficulties using this evidence as it is in excellent condition and text is completely visible as well. However there could have been some difficulties in translation as text has 2 differently identified scripts( khotanese & brahmi). Some condition of adoption are missing in translation of text otherwise it is easily understandable.
Use of this object: This object shows that adoption was a legal procedure back in 300-900. It offers a glimpse into the social structures and relationships of the time, shedding light on how adoptions were formalized and documented.

Description: his text, written in a combination of standard script and semicursive script calligraphy. he There are red check marks throughout the text which are the notations made by a priest at the Qianyuan Temple at Shazhou.
Difficulties using this object: The texts are not clear due to which it is very difficult for the readers to catch the words.
Use of this object: the script has been used as an for the outlines rules of mental and physical discipline for monks.

Document name: Śākyamuni in grotto of Vulture Peak with Jātaka scenes
Description:
Fr. of large silk painting evidently representing Buddha (Śākyamuni) in grotto of Vulture Peak, with Jātaka (?) scenes at sides.

Part only of L. half, much broken and all edges incomplete; but drawing well preserved and colour exceptionally fresh
Difficulties using this object: There is no such language barrier, as the text has been translated into English, apart from that the images are somehow scratched and unable to identigy them properly. Focuses the painting of a single person, I think Budha, but why and how are questions to be asked.
Use of this object: This article and the images give us information, how quickly Buddhism spread in this belt of Silk Road from India to China, then in the neighboring countries.

Description: This contract gives the conditions by which the two brothers of poor means agree to mortgage two parcels of their inherited estate totalling two and a half mou of land for a term of four years to their neighbour Luo Sichao in exchange for 15 piculs of wheat. The names and identifying marks of the three men appear at the close of the text along with those of two witnesses, Luo 's father Luo Anjin, and the Vinaya Master Fuhai.
Difficulties using this object: The text is in Chinese Language, some pages are fully blank nothing on them, it shows or the written has disappeared , or there has nothing written down.
Use of this object: This material give us the information about the tradition of agreement, which was used long by the people living on the Silk Road, and especially by the Chinese and it also give the evidence how the do agreement the criteria was also included.

Description: This contract gives the conditions by which the two brothers of poor means agree to mortgage two parcels of their inherited estate totalling two and a half mou of land for a term of four years to their neighbour Luo Sichao in exchange for 15 piculs of wheat. The names and identifying marks of the three men appear at the close of the text along with those of two witnesses, Luo 's father Luo Anjin, and the Vinaya Master Fuhai.
Difficulties using this object: The text is in Chinese Language, some pages are fully blank nothing on them, it shows or the written has disappeared , or there has nothing written down.
Use of this object: This material give us the information about the tradition of agreement, which was used long by the people living on the Silk Road, and especially by the Chinese and it also give the evidence how the do agreement the criteria was also included.

Description: This is a complete, but much discoloured and rotted document on leather. The Kharosthi scripts at the front of the tablet are cursive, and black.
Difficulties using this object: This paper is not finished properly. It is also been messed up, like torn or faded. That makes it hard for historians and others who want to study it. They rely on papers like this to learn about the past. But when a paper is incomplete and damaged, it's tough to figure out what it's saying. So, it's tricky for people to understand what really happened.
Use of this object: it helps experts like researchers and historians to learn about the Silk Road's past and the people who lived there. It gives important clues about a really important time in history when different cultures met and traded. This helps people from different backgrounds understand each other better.

Description: Scope and content : Discovered among an archive of official documents in a magristrates house in Cadota (Niya). Catalogued in Zwalf 1985: 40.
Difficulties using this object: The writing on the wood is very old, which makes it hard for researchers to understand. In some parts of the wood, the color has completely changed, and the writing is invisible.
Use of this object: it was cataloged in Zwalf 1985: 40, which implies that it might be of historical or cultural significance. The subject likely serves as a valuable resource for understanding the history, governance, or culture of Cadota (Niya) during the time period to which it belongs.

Document name: Ink on wood: vinaya text on rules for bathing
Description:
• A Manuscript on wood containing Vinaya text on rules for bathing in Gandhari Prakrit written in Kharosthi script.
  • It was discovered among an archive of official documents in a magistrate's house in Cadota(Niya)
  • Its depth is 2.5cm, height is 15cm, and width is 89.5cm.
  • The site from where it was found is situated approximately 50 miles north of modern Niya/Minfeng on the southern arm of the old Silk Road.
Difficulties using this object:
1) There are many scratches on the wood, which vanish the text from many places. So, it is challenging to understand the whole text.

2) In many places, the text on the wood has been rubbed off or faded off, making it difficult to understand the text meaningfully.
Use of this object:
• The presence of the Vinaya manuscript shows that the Buddhist preachings traveled over the Silk Road. 
  • This represents the cultural exchange over large distances by the Silk Road influencing the different communities along the route.

Document name: Silk fragments from tomb at Astana
Description: Printed silk shows red or blue ground with resist dyed pattern of repeating rosettes, formed of a circle of seven circular spots around a central spot, with larger single spots between.
Difficulties using this object: Silk fragments might have degraded over time, losing intricate details that could have provided clues about the lifestyle, cultural practices, or even economic status of the people who made or used them.
Use of this object: The presence of silk in tombs reflects the social status and cultural practices of the individuals buried there.  Silk fragments serve as evidence of the extensive trade networks that connected East and West along the Silk Road. By analyzing the origin of silk fibers, researchers can trace trade routes, identify production centers, and understand the economic relationships between different regions.

Description: Hanging in silk embroidery, showing life-size Śākyamuni Buddha on Gṛdhraūkūṭa. Ś. stands between a pair of disciples and Bodhisattvas; upper end of picture filled by canopy and floating Apsaras, lower by groups of kneeling donors and central panel for inscr. as in silk paintings. The ground is coarse natural-coloured linen, faced with light buff silk, which has mostly worn off in interspaces of figs. Design worked solid, in satin-stitch, throughout. Picture practically complete except for figs. of disciples who stand nearest Ś. and partly behind Bodhisattvas. These figs. fell along line of folding when hanging was put away, and have been for the most part eaten away.
Difficulties using this object: Unlike written records or archaeological artifacts, silk embroidery may not directly convey detailed information about daily life, social structures, or economic activities. Researchers must use other sources of evidence, such as historical texts, archaeological findings, and ethnographic studies, to complement their understanding of societies.
Use of this object: this embroidery depicts the religious affiliation of the people on the silk route. Bhuddism was the main religion in the region.

Document name: Text relating to the upkeep of roads in Khotanese.
Description:
• The military role in maintaining silk routes.
  • Critical Importance of Road Maintenance for Trade.
  • Resourceful Use of Paper and Bilingual Documentation.
  • quick action to address road maintenance issues.
Difficulties using this object:
•  
  • The document is torn from the edges.
  • Two languages are used.
  • A predicted date between 400 to 1000 means 600 years so difficult to contextualize.
Use of this object: it tell us about the Maintenance of silk routes.

Document name: Pothi Buddhist manuscript in Sanskrit on silk.
Description:
• A Buddhist manuscript is written in Sanskrit on silk.
  • The manuscript is created with ink on silk, with a chalk ground applied.
  • This unique silk manuscript is shaped in the South Asian pothi style.
Difficulties using this object:
The condition of documents is not good

It is in Sanskrit and is not widely spoken so more expertise required in understanding.
Use of this object:
• This document served as a cultural exchange between South Asia and China.
  • As a Buddhist manuscript, it was likely used for religious instruction, meditation, or ritual purposes

Description: Chinese Han-dynasty defensive structures (walls, forts, beacon towers etc) runnning north of Dunhuang in the Gobi desert.
Difficulties using this object:
Over time, thin wood manuscripts can degrade, leading to fading, or even complete loss of parts of the text.

Damage from moisture, pests, or physical wear can further complicate the readability of the manuscript

Ancient texts on thin wood don't have things like commas or spaces between words to help understand them better, unlike modern books. This makes it hard to read and figure out what the text means.
Use of this object:
It provides insights into ancient languages, cultures, beliefs, and practices, aiding historians and archaeologists in reconstructing past societies

Scholars can study ancient literature, poetry, or religious texts to understand literary traditions, storytelling techniques, and cultural values of bygone eras

Description:
Khotanese wooden tablet

Dandanuiliq: between the Khotan and Keriya rivers

height 20 centimetres, width 6 centimetres
Difficulties using this object:
Wooden tablets are often fragile and susceptible to decay over time. This can make it challenging to preserve the tablet and prevent further deterioration.

Wooden tablets can get damaged easily from things like water, bugs, and changes in temperature. This damage can make it harder to study and understand them compared to stronger materials like stone or metal.
Use of this object:
They often contain writings, drawings, or symbols that provide valuable information about ancient cultures, traditions, and daily life.

By studying wooden tablets alongside other archaeological findings, scholars can reconstruct historical timelines, events, and interactions between different civilizations.

Description:
• A silk painting portraying a magnificent depiction of six-armed Avalokitesvara, also known as Kuan-Yin, seated in a position of serene majesty.
  • The height of the silk painting is 84.4cm and its width is 61.7cm
  • In the silk painting, the Buddhist god is represented with six arms, each arm showing its divine qualities.
Difficulties using this object:
• There are some places where the paint has faded slightly.
  • There are some hidden messages in the silk painting which are challenging to decode
  • There are some light spots on the silk painting that ruin the paint in some places.
Use of this object:
• These artistic paintings played an important role in fostering mutual understanding with other ethnic communities
  • This shows how religious and cultural exchange took place on the Silk Road.
  • Passing through the Buddhist monasteries, many travelers and monks would have encountered the paintings of Avalokitesvara and performed their ritual offerings.
  • This shows that the Silk Road was a big source of spreading culture and religion.

Description: The artwork was previously credited to the Monks Hongjing, Pude, Jishan, and Liaochen, who were active during the 8th to 9th centuries in China.
Difficulties using this object: Using Buddhist deity representations requires cultural sensitivity, respect for religious beliefs, and accuracy to avoid misinterpretation or offense.
Use of this object: The use of representations of three Buddhist deities and their attendants necessitates cultural awareness, religious reverence, and authenticity to honor their significance accurately.

Description: Piece of striped silk inscribed with one line of Kharosthi characters. Silk of fine texture with two woven bands of narrow closely-spaced lines. The text consists of nine short kharosthi inscriptions, five of them complete. They contain prayers in Prakrit for the welfare of pious donors. See Boyer's article in Journal Asiatique, 17 (1911): 431
Difficulties using this object: The document, found fragmented, presents challenges for readers due to its scattered nature, hindering comprehension and interpretation.
Use of this object:
The fragmented document likely contains prayers in Prakrit, aimed at securing the well-being of virtuous donors, while also providing insight into the characters depicted in Kharosthi script.

The fragmented document likely contains prayers in Prakrit, aimed at securing the well-being of virtuous donors, while also providing insight into the characters depicted in Kharosthi script.

Top of Form
